**Gauntlets of power**, often abbreviated to **GoP**, are a type of [magical](/wiki/Magical_item "Magical item") [gloves](/wiki/Gloves "Gloves") that appear in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. They are made of [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron"), and have a [randomized appearance](/wiki/Randomized_appearance "Randomized appearance") when [unidentified](/wiki/Identification "Identification"); the default one associated with them is a pair of [riding gloves](/wiki/Riding_gloves "Riding gloves").[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Description](#Description)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)
  - [3.1 Identification](#Identification)

- [4 History](#History)

- [5 Variants](#Variants)

  - [5.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [5.2 GruntHack](#GruntHack)
  - [5.3 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [5.4 EvilHack](#EvilHack)

- [6 References](#References)

## Generation

[Player monsters](/wiki/Player_monster "Player monster") on the [Astral Plane](/wiki/Astral_Plane "Astral Plane") that generate with a [war hammer](/wiki/War_hammer "War hammer") will always generate with gauntlets of power, while other player monsters have an effective 7⁄40 chance (\~17.5%) of [generating with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") gauntlets of power.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

## Description

While worn, gauntlets of power grant 1 base point of [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") and sets a character's [strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength") to 25 regardless of [beatitude](/wiki/Beatitude "Beatitude"). Wearing or removing gauntlets of power will [auto-identify](/wiki/Auto-identify "Auto-identify") them. Strength cannot be [exercised](/wiki/Exercise "Exercise") while wearing gauntlets of power, although innate strength increases will still occur as normal. A -2 [to-hit](/wiki/To-hit "To-hit") penalty is applied when shooting with any type of [bow](/wiki/Bow "Bow") while wearing gauntlets of power.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

[Mjollnir](/wiki/Mjollnir "Mjollnir") can only be thrown by a character with 25 strength, which for all practical purposes requires gauntlets of power.

Monsters wearing gauntlets of power add 3-6 damage to their [weapon](/wiki/Weapon "Weapon") attacks, with no effect on monsters that cannot wield weapons.[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)

## Strategy

- *Main article: [Strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength")*

Strength helps increase [carrying capacity](/wiki/Carrying_capacity "Carrying capacity"), the chance for attacks to hit, the damage of melee attacks and projectile attacks not involving a [launcher](/wiki/Launcher "Launcher"), and the range of projectiles other than fired [crossbow bolts](/wiki/Crossbow_bolt "Crossbow bolt"). However, non-[elven](/wiki/Elf_\(starting_race\) "Elf (starting race)") characters can obtain most of these benefits from reaching 18/\*\* strength through other means; the only further benefits from gauntlets of power in those cases are increased carrying capacity, projectile range, and the ability to throw Mjollnir.

While neither necessary to the point of using a [wish](/wiki/Wish "Wish") nor commonplace in [ascension kits](/wiki/Ascension_kit "Ascension kit"), gauntlets of power are still a viable choice of armor for the long term. Although they interfere with \[\[spellcasting], [Wizards](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard") may still want to wear them to shore up their strength: a 4% general spell [failure rate](/wiki/Spellcasting#Calculating_spell_success_rate "Spellcasting") with 18 [intelligence](/wiki/Intelligence "Intelligence") (or 3% with 19+ intelligence) may be acceptably low if not wearing a [robe](/wiki/Robe "Robe") or any other metal armor.

Less adept casters may experience a much greater increase in spell failure rates, and as such those planning to utilize spells often or in-combat may want different gloves. Conversely, those dedicated to non-magical combat such as [Barbarians](/wiki/Barbarian "Barbarian") may prefer gauntlets of power; a strength level of 18/01 or above makes the bonuses of gauntlets of power somewhat more marginal, and is also easy to obtain for non-elven characters.

For characters considering replacing their gauntlets of power at a later point, it may benefit them to remove these gloves while actively or passively training strength (e.g., solving [Sokoban](/wiki/Sokoban "Sokoban")), unless doing so severely impacts combat performance.

### Identification

Gauntlets of power will always auto-identify when worn or removed, and are also the only gloves to be metallic and weigh 30 [aum](/wiki/Aum "Aum"). Being made of iron even allows them to be distinguished from other gloves without wearing them: using a [touchstone](/wiki/Touchstone "Touchstone") on unidentified gauntlets of power will produce its distinctive "scritch, scritch" noise.

## History

Gauntlets of power first appear in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0").

The extra damage for monster weapon attacks is added in [NetHack 3.6.1](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.1 "NetHack 3.6.1").[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), gauntlets of power set your strength to 18/\*\* and further modify it based on the gauntlets' enchantment, e.g. a +1 pair will give you 19 strength, while a -1 pair will give you 18/99. Valkyries can safely enchant gauntlets of power up to +7, which allows them to gain the 25 strength required to throw Mjollnir.

The [spinach](/wiki/Spinach "Spinach")-filled hidden chest behind the secret passage in the southwestern portion of [Grund's Stronghold](/wiki/Grund%27s_Stronghold "Grund's Stronghold") has a 1⁄3 chance of containing a cursed +1 pair of gauntlets of power.

### GruntHack

In [GruntHack](/wiki/GruntHack "GruntHack"), power is an [object property](/wiki/Object_properties#Armor-specific_properties "Object properties") that gloves and other armor can have, and can occur on already-magical armor - a blessed, [greased](/wiki/Greased "Greased") and [fireproofed](/wiki/Fireproof "Fireproof") +3 pair of [dragonhide](/wiki/Dragonhide "Dragonhide") [gauntlets of dexterity](/wiki/Gauntlets_of_dexterity "Gauntlets of dexterity") and power is perhaps the best [wish](/wiki/Wish "Wish") available for the gloves slot.

Monsters are capable of making wishes, and may wish for blessed, greased and fixed +3 gauntlets of power if they are not [strong](/wiki/Strong "Strong").

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack") and [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack"), gauntlets of power confer 1 base AC, 1 base [DR](/wiki/DR "DR") and 25 strength while worn.

There are a few [artifact](/wiki/Artifact "Artifact") pairs of gauntlets of power:

- [The Gauntlets of Spell Power](/wiki/DNetHack_artifacts#Gauntlets_of_Spell_Power "DNetHack artifacts") are unaligned [silvered](/wiki/Silver "Silver") gauntlets of power that are made of iron (which harms elves, drow and vampires). While worn, they add silver damage to unarmed attacks, grant a +1 bonus to skill level for all spells without changing failure rates, doubles damage for beam and ray spells, and confer [half spell damage](/wiki/Half_spell_damage "Half spell damage").
- [The Premium Heart](/wiki/DNetHack_artifacts#Premium_Heart "DNetHack artifacts") is an unaligned set of gauntlets of power that adds their enchantment to [dexterity](/wiki/Dexterity "Dexterity") as the [gauntlets of dexterity](/wiki/Gauntlets_of_dexterity "Gauntlets of dexterity") do while worn, and can be enchanted safely to +7. They unlock the martial arts skill when given as a sacrifice gift. While worn, Premium Heart also confers +1 to-hit and double damage to unarmed attacks, give no additional spell failure penalty to [Monks](/wiki/Monk "Monk"), and unarmed attacks have a skill level in 20 chance of staggering the opponent - most of all, they gain an additional +1x damage multiplier for each status property afflicting the wearer.
- [The Godhands](/wiki/DNetHack_artifacts#Godhands "DNetHack artifacts") are lawful [golden](/wiki/Gold_\(material\) "Gold (material)") gauntlets of power that set dexterity to 25 while worn and can be enchanted to +7. While worn, they also confer +1d20 to-hit and +1d10 damage to unarmed attacks, give no additional spell failure penalty to Monks, grant [drain resistance](/wiki/Drain_resistance "Drain resistance"), and deal extra damage when blessed or cursed: blessed Godhands deal +3d7 unholy damage to unholy-haters in addition to the base item's +2d9 unholy damage, while blessed Godhands deal +3d7 holy damage to holy-haters in addition to the base item's +1d20 holy damage.
- [The Grappler's Grasp](/wiki/DNetHack_artifacts#Grappler.27s_Grasp "DNetHack artifacts") is an unaligned set of gauntlets of power that confers +1 to-hit and +1d6 damage while worn, and grabs monsters on a successful unarmed attack - while grabbed, monsters take at least one d6 of crushing damage each turn, with the amount dependent on skill level: 1d6 at Basic skill or lower, 2d6 at Skilled or Expert, and 3d6 at Master or higher, with +1d6 if you have the martial arts skill.
- [The Great Claws of Urdlen](/wiki/DNetHack_artifacts#Great_Claws_of_Urdlen "DNetHack artifacts") are a chaotic set of gauntlets of power that serve as the [crowning](/wiki/Crowning "Crowning") gift for chaotic [gnome](/wiki/Gnome_\(starting_race\) "Gnome (starting race)") characters, and enable them to train martial arts to Grand Master. While worn, they grant +1d10 to-hit and double damage to unarmed attacks, along with doubling the unarmed damage die to 1d8 and adding their enchantment to that damage. They also set [constitution](/wiki/Constitution "Constitution") to 25 while worn, can be used as a [digging tool](/wiki/Digging_tool "Digging tool"), and [invoking](/wiki/Invoking "Invoking") them causes an [earthquake](/index.php?title=Earthquake\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Earthquake (page does not exist)").

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), the [Gauntlets of Purity](/wiki/Gauntlets_of_Purity "Gauntlets of Purity") are an [artifact](/wiki/Artifact "Artifact") pair of gauntlets of power made of silver.

Monsters are capable of making wishes as in GruntHack, and may wish for blessed erodeproofed gauntlets of power with an enchantment from +1 to +4 if they can wear them and are not strong.

Early [wishes](/wiki/Wish "Wish") for [illithid](/wiki/Illithid_\(starting_race\) "Illithid (starting race)") characters often include gauntlets of power to offset their low strength and carrying capacity, with [bone](/wiki/Bone "Bone") and [wood](/wiki/Wood "Wood") as popular [choices of material](/wiki/Object_materials_\(EvilHack\) "Object materials (EvilHack)") due to being lighter and spellcaster-friendly. [Stone](/wiki/Stone "Stone") is also viable and even provides an extra point of [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") - though it is heavier, this is somewhat offset by keeping them worn where possible.

Gauntlets of power, often abbreviated to GoP, are a type of magical gloves that appear in NetHack. They are made of iron, and have a randomized appearance when unidentified; the default one associated with them is a pair of riding gloves.[1]

Generation

Description

While worn, gauntlets of power grant 1 base point of AC and sets a character's strength to 25 regardless of beatitude. Wearing or removing gauntlets of power will auto-identify them. Strength cannot be exercised while wearing gauntlets of power, although innate strength increases will still occur as normal. A -2 to-hit penalty is applied when shooting with any type of bow while wearing gauntlets of power.[3]

Mjollnir can only be thrown by a character with 25 strength, which for all practical purposes requires gauntlets of power.

Monsters wearing gauntlets of power add 3-6 damage to their weapon attacks, with no effect on monsters that cannot wield weapons.[4]

Strategy

Main article: Strength

Strength helps increase carrying capacity, the chance for attacks to hit, the damage of melee attacks and projectile attacks not involving a launcher, and the range of projectiles other than fired crossbow bolts. However, non-elven characters can obtain most of these benefits from reaching 18/** strength through other means; the only further benefits from gauntlets of power in those cases are increased carrying capacity, projectile range, and the ability to throw Mjollnir.

While neither necessary to the point of using a wish nor commonplace in ascension kits, gauntlets of power are still a viable choice of armor for the long term. Although they interfere with [[spellcasting], Wizards may still want to wear them to shore up their strength: a 4% general spell failure rate with 18 intelligence (or 3% with 19+ intelligence) may be acceptably low if not wearing a robe or any other metal armor.

Less adept casters may experience a much greater increase in spell failure rates, and as such those planning to utilize spells often or in-combat may want different gloves. Conversely, those dedicated to non-magical combat such as Barbarians may prefer gauntlets of power; a strength level of 18/01 or above makes the bonuses of gauntlets of power somewhat more marginal, and is also easy to obtain for non-elven characters.

For characters considering replacing their gauntlets of power at a later point, it may benefit them to remove these gloves while actively or passively training strength (e.g., solving Sokoban), unless doing so severely impacts combat performance.

Identification

Gauntlets of power will always auto-identify when worn or removed, and are also the only gloves to be metallic and weigh 30 aum. Being made of iron even allows them to be distinguished from other gloves without wearing them: using a touchstone on unidentified gauntlets of power will produce its distinctive "scritch, scritch" noise.

History

Gauntlets of power first appear in NetHack 3.0.0.

The extra damage for monster weapon attacks is added in NetHack 3.6.1.[5]

Variants

SLASH'EM

GruntHack

In GruntHack, power is an object property that gloves and other armor can have, and can occur on already-magical armor - a blessed, greased and fireproofed +3 pair of dragonhide gauntlets of dexterity and power is perhaps the best wish available for the gloves slot.

Monsters are capable of making wishes, and may wish for blessed, greased and fixed +3 gauntlets of power if they are not strong.

In dNetHack and notdNetHack, gauntlets of power confer 1 base AC, 1 base DR and 25 strength while worn.

While worn, they add silver damage to unarmed attacks, grant a +1 bonus to skill level for all spells without changing failure rates, doubles damage for beam and ray spells, and confer half spell damage.
  • The Premium Heart is an unaligned set of gauntlets of power that adds their enchantment to dexterity as the gauntlets of dexterity do while worn, and can be enchanted safely to +7.   • The Godhands are lawful golden gauntlets of power that set dexterity to 25 while worn and can be enchanted to +7. While worn, they grant +1d10 to-hit and double damage to unarmed attacks, along with doubling the unarmed damage die to 1d8 and adding their enchantment to that damage. While worn, they add silver damage to unarmed attacks, grant a +1 bonus to skill level for all spells without changing failure rates, doubles damage for beam and ray spells, and confer [[half spell damage]]. * [[dNetHack artifacts#Premium Heart|The Premium Heart]] is an unaligned set of gauntlets of power that adds their enchantment to [[dexterity]] as the [[gauntlets of dexterity]] do while worn, and can be enchanted safely to +7. They unlock the martial arts skill when given as a sacrifice gift. While worn, Premium Heart also confers +1 to-hit and double damage to unarmed attacks, give no additional spell failure penalty to [[Monk]]s, and unarmed attacks have a skill level in 20 chance of staggering the opponent - most of all, they gain an additional +1x damage multiplier for each status property afflicting the wearer. * [[dNetHack artifacts#Godhands|The Godhands]] are lawful [[Gold (material)|golden]] gauntlets of power that set dexterity to 25 while worn and can be enchanted to +7. While worn, they also confer +1d20 to-hit and +1d10 damage to unarmed attacks, give no additional spell failure penalty to Monks, grant [[drain resistance]], and deal extra damage when blessed or cursed: blessed Godhands deal +3d7 unholy damage to unholy-haters in addition to the base item's +2d9 unholy damage, while blessed Godhands deal +3d7 holy damage to holy-haters in addition to the base item's +1d20 holy damage. * [[dNetHack artifacts#Grappler's Grasp|The Grappler's Grasp]] is an unaligned set of gauntlets of power that confers +1 to-hit and +1d6 damage while worn, and grabs monsters on a successful unarmed attack - while grabbed, monsters take at least one d6 of crushing damage each turn, with the amount dependent on skill level: 1d6 at Basic skill or lower, 2d6 at Skilled or Expert, and 3d6 at Master or higher, with +1d6 if you have the martial arts skill. * [[dNetHack artifacts#Great Claws of Urdlen|The Great Claws of Urdlen]] are a chaotic set of gauntlets of power that serve as the [[crowning]] gift for chaotic [[Gnome (starting race)|gnome]] characters, and enable them to train martial arts to Grand Master. While worn, they grant +1d10 to-hit and double damage to unarmed attacks, along with doubling the unarmed damage die to 1d8 and adding their enchantment to that damage. They also set [[constitution]] to 25 while worn, can be used as a [[digging tool]], and [[invoking]] them causes an [[earthquake]]. ===EvilHack=== In [[EvilHack]], the [[Gauntlets of Purity]] are an [[artifact]] pair of gauntlets of power made of silver. Monsters are capable of making wishes as in GruntHack, and may wish for blessed erodeproofed gauntlets of power with an enchantment from +1 to +4 if they can wear them and are not strong. Early [[wish]]es for [[Illithid (starting race)|illithid]] characters often include gauntlets of power to offset their low strength and carrying capacity, with [[bone]] and [[wood]] as popular [[Object materials (EvilHack)|choices of material]] due to being lighter and spellcaster-friendly. [[Stone]] is also viable and even provides an extra point of [[AC]] - though it is heavier, this is somewhat offset by keeping them worn where possible. ==References== {{nethack-367}} [[Category:Gloves]]
